intro: Gilia virgata var. typica, commonly known as the common gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Mexico. It is a member of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. The plant produces showy, radially symmetric flowers that are usually pink to purple in color, with five petals and a prominent yellow center. It has slender, branching stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. Gilia virgata var. typica is known for its early blooming period, often flowering in late spring to early summer.
